div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Shortest, calmest, most beautiful sea passage to Europe. Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Sofia, Belgrade, Budapest, Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Chios, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli, Constantinople.

KHARTOUM IN 3 DAYS. Express Steamers leave Suez Docks 5 p.m. every Wedensday for Port Sudan (and Suakin) in connection with Sudan Government Railways Express Luxe service to Kharteum, arriving 8 p.m. Saturdays.

Steamers leave from Suez 5 p.m. every Monday evening for JEDDA, calling one week at Tor, El Wedj, Yambo, Jedda; and the following week at Tor, Yambo, Jedda, Port Sudan, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, ADEN.
For freight or passage apply the Co.'s agencies Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, or for passage only to THOS, COOK & SON, HAMBURG-AMERIKA LINE, REISE-BUREAT or other Tourist Agenecies.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: A BOON FOR CAIRO
div.p: Even the most optimistic supporter of the "Lady romer Dispensaries" hantly expected that the growth and progress of these institutions would be a rapid as has proved to be the anse Pounded about two years ago for the alleviation of the sufferings of the ailing children of the poor, it sprang at once into popularity, and each year bringe ever increasing numbers of patients for treatment, and whereas the number which passed through in November 1906 renched only 15H7, quite four times that number were treated during the corresponding month of last year Every little patient who is brought to the dispensary must be accompanied by its mother or some responsible member of its family in order that the treatment accorded it may be explained, and the first principles of hundaging, hygiene etc taught. Thus the

knowledge of elementary treatment necessary in case of sickness, accident or disease, is being rapidly spread among the poorer inhabitants of Cairo, and as it is undoubtedly due to the lack of this knowledge that the death rate among infants and children in the town remains at such an alarmingly high standard, it is impossible to over rate the importance of the institution But the expenses attached to the undertaking are necessarily great, and are ever increasing the number of patients multiply, we would therefore remind our readers that though the subscriptions now exceed LE 5,000 there is still an urgent need of fonds, and that subscriptions are cordially invited by the committee appointed for the collection of money for this purpose. All the banks and most of the large companies of Cairo have already subscribed handsomely to the fand, but there are still countless public bodies and private individuals who, probably from want of thought, have omitted to place their names on the list of subscribers, and we feel sure that these will need no further inducement to do so than the obvious good accomplished by the undertaking ho too offer them. It will be remembered that on Lord Cromer's departure large and influential committee representing all interests and Nationalities was formed under the presidency of the Prime Minister, and that after a great deal of discussion it was decided to raise subscriptions in appreciation and memory of Lord Cromer's work in Egypt and as Lord Cromer bad expressed his wish that this useful work of Lady Cromer should be continued, it was decided that the subscriptions should be applied to the development and extension of Lady Cromer's dispensaries. A subcommittee was formed to collect foods and the Governor of the National Bank of Egypt wm appointed honorary treasurer. All subscriptions and enquiries should be therefore, ad dressed to the Governor of the National Bank, Cairo, where any one interested will also be shewn the full list of subscribers. We trust hat the support which this institution has already received may be increased in a manner which will enable the promoters to cope with the increasing demands upon their food Dot only will those who subscribe to these funds be assisting one of the most far reaching schemes of charity in the country, they are also contributing to a monument of Lord Cromer's work.

div.head: BRITISH CONSULAR COURT
div.p: A Cairo contemporary in pursuance of its invariable policy of attacking the methods of the English administration in Egypt has devoted two columns of its valuable space without having even taken the trouble to ascertain the truth of its allegations to the condemnation of an alleged action of the British Consular court. Our contemporary informs us that this amazing example of judicial irregularity is that the British Consular Court has condemned the Badan Government to pay an indemnity of LE 2,500 to Mr. Levy British national." The source from whence this startling information springs renders denial almost unnecessary However it is just possible that there may be persons among the general public of Egypt gifted with a credulity equal to that of our contemporary, it is perhaps as well to publish the truth of the matter. To begin with the account of the affair quoted above is absolutely false, the facts of the case being as follows. Differences having arisen between Mr. Levy, gentlemen of Italian extraction, and the Sudan Authorities, it was decided to refer the matter to arbitration, and Me Alban, the British Consul in Cairo, wm mutually chosen to act us arbitrator. After examination of the case his decision favoured Mr. Levy and he gave his judgment accordingly, his decision being of course accepted a final and binding by both the parties concerned. Mr. Alban is arbitrating this matter was acting as an individual only, his position in relation to the Consular Court having nothing whatever to do with the affair. It happened that he was chosen as being possessed of knowledge which in such case would enable him to treat the seatter on strictly just terms, but it was Mr. Alban the person and not Mr. Alban of the British Consulate wbo arbitrated, and had his position been that of sbop keeper, or his name Smith, Jones or Mustapha, his finding would have carried equal weight provided that he had been mata ally obosen to perform the task of arbitration by the contesting parties. And to another bubble has burst and credit for yet another ingenious invention must be accorded to our imaginative contemporary

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT
div.p: MR ROBERTSON'S REGRETS
SIR EGREY'S REPLY
(Gazette's Special Service)

London, Saturday Mi Robertson moved an amendment to the Adres regretting that progress had not been made in the direction of self government in Egypt. He admitted that the material con Hition of the people hat nhatantially improved under the British, but this should have been accompanied by a gradual guarded, reasonable Progress towards self government.

Sir E Grey made a fine speech defending the British officials, pointing out that the difficulties of the Egyptian ministration were more severe than in the case of any Oriental Government If we applied to rapidly, to race which had been crushed, our principles it might very well province corruption, con fusion, disorder, and oppression

Sir E Grey paid a high compliment to Sir Eldon Gorst's work dir E Grey bal deliberately refrained from bordening him with instructions, because he wanted his advice after he had formed his opinions impartially. He repented in conclusion that progress must be slow if they were not foster reaction
Mr Robertson withdrew his amendment

div.head: AT THE RACE. A FASHIONABLE GATHERING.
div.p: (FROM OUR LADY CORRESPONDENT)

Everybody took advantage of the sunny afternoon and the comparatively balmy weather to put in their appearance at Ghezireh where many exciting events were promised. H.H the believe was in his private stand, and all the world with but few exceptions were to be seen dressed in their best, am using themselves in the adjoining enclosure and paddock It was gout be running oneself again ander blue skies, good to admire the beautiful view, good to see the satin coated horses as they thunder si past the winning post, the silken jackets of their nders gleaming in the sunlight, and it wa gw to enjoy all these pleasurable things in the company of ones good friends

It is at Ghezireh almost more than at any other place in Cairo, that one in struck by the Room Looks of the feminine portion of our community and by the excellence of their taste in dress. Par eser would it be to describe those who did not become their clothes yesterday than make a mention of all those whose garments acted as charming foils to the graces of their person Lady Gort is always gowned with perfect taste and in the latest expression of the modes and we noticed many others whose frorks ets were of the most delightful description. Mrs. Rom was one of the best dressed woter present her cloth princess dress very beautifully cut, though but little of it could be seen under the long short waisted coat of desert-sand colour with glimpses of oriental embroidery showing at the neck. Mrs. Maclean had ons wonderfully fitting cloth gown of pale grey her large plumed hat being lined with a deeper shade, the big bunch of violets tucked into her corsage giving just the necessary touch of relief. Mrs. Morgan was also in grey, finely tucked chiffon with many insertions of Ince dyer to match Her hat, worn rather far Park was encircled with long white feathers And she wore very long white feather
Miss Fitzelarence hal on a perfect frock of doll purple cloth, the narrow century being of old tissite, her pretty hat was named with shaded roses and lilac, and when carried
lively mutt and boa of soft brown feathers The Misses York were in charming frooks of

stel blue, the wide cretelles being draped over the aunty corsages of lace embroidered with blue. Miss Byrne WAN in a pretty trock of brown with shaded rises in ber hat and Mi Chiuse was wearing a lovely large hat trimmed with brown aigrettes and bow of ribbon with her neat tailor suit of tussore Miss Ridgeway was in handsome frock of white cloth with a large black picture bat the Miss Annesley were wearing pretty wift trucks of pastel blue and fawn respectively with soft corsages of love, and very becoming hats "The big white matin clow he hat worn by one of the Miss Yorks Was wreatbed about with waterlilies, and looked very well in conJunction to the smart little silk coat she wore with ber pale blue dress

Mr Greville was in rather severe suit of dark blue, with rose trimmed Leghorn hat And fine sables with bat trimmed with purple velvet and wings and shaded roses M188 Barties lawrence was wearing address of palest grey The Counters. Wachtmeister had on lovely custofermine over adress of grey filet. There were several handsome fur coats worn Mrs Nolan slipped on hers over her pretty frock of pale blue and Miss Nungovich was also wearing a dainty little loose garment of white fur er her filmy robe of pale pink chiffon

Time does not allow of further descriptions of pretty frocks, though many others were noticed. Among those present were the Count and Counter von Bernstorff Sir John and Lady Rogers, Sir Horace Pinehing, Lord Edward Cecil. Capt. Morgan, Mr. and Mrs. Waterlow, Miss Porrester, Mr. Russell, Mr. and Mrs. Kershaw and Mrs. Lowell, Mrs. de B. Carey and Princes lerene, Mr and Mrs Chat terton Adams, Mr and Mrs Peckett, Mr and Miss Chase, Mr. and Mrs. A Joseph, Mrs. and Miss Shakoor, Mrs. Merkl and Miss Mande, Mrs and Miss Miller, Mr. and Mrs. Archer, Mr. and Mrs. Foaden. Mr. and Mine Stapleton Cotton, Col. and Mrs Herbert, Sir Reginald and Lady Cakes, Mr Gantber, Miss Churchill. Captain and Mr. Majendie and Miss Davidson, Mrs and Miss Tuck, Mrs. Febalex and Miss Frost, Sir Horace Pinehing, Miss Stuart Davidson, Capt. and Mrs. Clifford Hall, Misa de Bilibaki, Mr. and Mrs. Carver, Capt. and Mrs Schreiber, Mr and Mrs. Schreiber, Miss Schreiber, etc.
THE KHARGA OASIS.
A GREAT ENTERPRISE

The great Oasis of Kharga which has been 80 much before the public lately by reason of the Western Oasis Railway which connecta it with the valley of the Nile, is no untried tract of land which may or may not prove to be of agricultural value for the experimental stages of the work undertaken by the Corporation of Western Egypt both regards land development and water supply can now be said to have concluded, and the real work to have begun Porty wo borrms have been drilled up to the present time, and without exception the results have fully justified the expectations of the promoters of this great enterprise, for an average yield of about seventy five gallons of water per minute has been obtained and the maximum delivery has reached four hundred gallons per minute for one bore. The natural prodnots of the Onsis can also be taken as a very fair criterion of what may be expected when the land has been traster, for there are in Kharga some 60,000 date, and other fruit trees, all of them bearing fruit equal to the very best samples which have been obtained in any part of Paypt and the Corporation has already planted some 14,000 of various kinds. Cotton, barley and other crops have already been tried and found to yield produce of excellent quality, while the bern cropa ahew promise of reaching a standard At least equal to those of the Nile valley Altogether there is at the Corporations headquarters a total of about 700 teddans that has been or is, under crop, including about 350) of winter crop at the present time and about me much more under preparation, and water supply sufficient for the irrigation of about 10 fidans of winter or 607 of summer cultivation is also available now, and this supply will of course be sugumenteltrom from time to time by the boning of fresh wells m circumstances render it necessary, while the arterian supply can be largely supplemented by surface water from sakiehs. When it 13 considered that all the crops have been tried upon practically "green" land, the natural richness of the soil will be apparent to all, and this land, subjected to a regular and wentifierultivation should yield results in all respects equal, if not superior, to those obtainable in any part of the country

With the opening of the Western Oasis Railway, this great with its va arreul cultural possessions and its huge groves of date palms and fruit trees has been brought to within an eight hours run of the Nile Valley Dear Parshut, and within nineteen hours of Cairo, thus reclaiming to Egypt one of her most important ports, whore value to this country can hardly be overestimated Mr. Manville, the Chairman of the Company, in wbone hands the development of this, and the still more distant Ones Dakbla and Parafrah, lien, in his recent speech to the guests of the corporation in the sin of K bang, expressed his gratitude to HE Jobraon Pasha to whom the founding and subsequent organisation of the Corporation of Western Egypt wm primarily due, and then sentiment will be echoed by all who have the interests of this country at heart, for it is not only a field for agricultural enterprise that the thesis of value, it also contains many important and unique relies on the past, besides being a valuable addition to the health resorts of the world was the appenited report of the Resident Medical Officer of the anis will prve
The maximum reling of the thermometer for the year was 120° F. on June 15th, and the minimum 27.5° F For January 27th
The prevailing winds are from the North bully blowing strongly during the Iny and falling during the night

During the summer clouds were rarely seen and during the winter months although the sky Wax OCCASIOnally clouded ver, bright shine was the role. There we practically no rainfall during the year, slight showers near ring on three days only

Water Supply - The water, which is obtained next by deep borings is pure, palatable drinking water, free from organic contamination and harmful mineral salts. It is charged with free nitrogen which rises in bubbles from the water as it ifte from the wells As there in practically no infall and consequently to surface water, contamination from the surface of the evil almost impossible The iron oming used in the Corporation's wells also prevent the entrance of the higher level water which might carry organic matter from neighbouring villages or cultivation
The temperature of the water x It issues from the wells is in nearly all cases, about F, and excellent baths tight be constructed without artificial beat.

The water of many of the old wells, notably those near Kasr el Gheta, contain iron salta. The Ain el Ghuet water is au aci Julous chalybeate water, containing, in addition to iron, sulphates and chlorides of magnesium, potassium, sodium and calcium It should prove serviceable in cases of anæmis

Conclusions - The dryness of the air and the prevalence of cool North winds render the summer climate much more bearable than an inspection of the maximum temperatures would lead one to suppose. The coolness of the night is also a great advantage.
Owing to the extreme dryness of the air, the

climate is nimirably adapted for invalida suffering from all lung complaints. Anemic individuals and convalescents from almost any serious illness would also be benefited in the Oasis (Signed H. H. BAKER
Medical Officer Headquarters, Khargeh Omnis

March 29th, 1907 In three days when Luxor, Assouan, and even the more remote fields of the Sadan have been visited, written, and talked about until every traveller i Conversant with their least details, it is interesting to find a new sphere of interest which bear all the essentials of Egyptian interest together with the advantage of proximity to Cairo And me only are the ruins of ancient Egypt of surpassing interest Mexisting in this remote spot in the centre of the Lybian desert. The present day existence of the inhabitants, differing entirely from that of the dwellers in the Nile valley, or indeed from those of any other known part of the world, opens up new and interesting field for enquiry and study. K harga town itself in for the mont part built in dark channels under the earth, the streets winding about in a maze of pitchy black and forming veritable city of eternal night. In no part of Egypt in the age and the mystery of the country brought so clearly before one, u bere where one finds the quiet stream of life flowing serenely on an it most have done for many hundreds of years pant, untouched by the whirlwind of change which was taking place in the outer world Moch was the mode of life in the days of the Roman occupation, most the daily life of the people be to day, and it is not without

vague feeling of regret that one anticipates the change which must necessarily creep into the being of these dwellers in the western desert now that the old days of camel transport Are over and steam and steel have invaded the quietude of their lives Trains are to run regularly between Karga Junction on the State Railways and the Oasis twice a week and preparations have already been made to accomodate a certain number of visitors. The Corporation of Western Egypt have published an interesting little booklet dealing with the main features of interest to be found in the Oaxis and it will be surprising if visits to Kharga will not take a prominent part in the programme of the visitor to Egypt in the future has a visit to the ruins of Kamak in the past the preliminary works of exploiting have already announced, been completely, it only now remains to reap the good which the land promises the railway was of necessity artsy affair but it was of paramount importance to the future of the Oasis, and its completion leaves the company free to devote their whole energies to the development of the land. There are also mineral possibilities, but there are a secondary consideration, and will be dealt with only when the agricultural future of the land has been assured beyond the possibility of doubt.

div.head: DISCOVERY AT THEBES.
div.p: ANCIENT EGYPTIAN JEWELLERY
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT)

Luxor th January The invaders working for Mr Theodore TAVI under the direction Mr Ayrton, have come wire beautiful gold ornaments which are marked with the cartouche of Seti II and are believed to have been worn by the queen
This hned alpine measure for the disappointment over the recently discovered ton which proved to be empty

"The jewellery was embedded in the meal of shaft leading to a tomb and was doubtless hidden there ages ago by robbers who had plundered the royal burial place it is said to he exceedingly beautiful and a full account will be published after experts have seen it Report peaks of two gold coronets, many rings bracelets and earrings all of the finest workmanship and in perfect preservation

The tenure will be sent to the Cairo museum in de roure, for though half share fordinary "find goes to the extAVA tar in the of unique things such as these Jewels which would also be in value by being airtel, being all of one period and the
party of one queen nothing is kept by the finder

Mr Theodore Davis where his devoted much time and a liberal share of his wealth to the work in which he is deeply interested in to be congratulated on his latest discovery It will be remembered that the tombs of Queen Tii and of her father and mother wbieb yielded such interesting funeral furniture including gold plated chariot now in the
airo Museum, were found by him, the former only a year ago and the latter in 1905. No EXCAVAtor of recent years has been more lucky than Mr Davis

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE DANCE
div.p: Owing no doubt to the preceding gaiety of the week, the dance at Ghezireh Palace on Thursday night was not so brilliant a spectacle As usual and the eccentric dancing of a certain party of guests attracted perhaps more atten tion than it would otherwise bave done. Many of our American visitors are noted for their skill and address in the ball room; bat it is most unusual to find couples at Ghezireh Palace dancing in mode more suitable to
bank holiday report than in hotel which has always been considered one of the most select in Cairo

div.head: WR WARSICK'S CONCERT
div.p: The contine concert given by Mr. Marsick at the Khedival Hotel yesterday attracted large and fashionable audience, which must have been very gratifying to that talented violinist. From wbat we heard yesterday we have no hesitation in saying that Mr. Marsick is a perfect master of his instrument. His style reminded us ocasionally somewhat of Romanzi, and his delicate handling of the several items contributed was very highly appreciated He was perhaps heart at bis best in a sobata by Cesar Pranks which was admirably played. Mr. Marnick has a most valuable ally in Mlle Panlette Demeri who contributed two pianoforte solo executed in

manner rarely heard in Alexandria. By the keen perception of light and shade, coupled with depth of feeling which characterised ber entire performance Mlle Demeri proved berself musician of very high order. The solos played were not mentioned on the programme, but we think they were by Chopin. The other numbers were contributed by Mlle D'Espiney who has a soprano voice of good timbre aod sang in exoelleut taste, and in some instances very daintily, several songs by well known composers among the best of which were the "Air de la Naiade d'Armide by Glook, and "Villanello" by Berlion, which were exceedingly well rendered.
TELEGRAMS.

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT
MR. ROBERTSON'S AMENDMENT
div.p: SIR E GREY'S REPLY
LAND, February 1 House of Commons. Mr. Robertson move

Amendment to the Address urging consti tational reform in Egypt. While Lord Cromer's administration, he said, benefitted the Egyp tians materially it was marrel by mistakes and did not promote moral development. Sir & Grey deprecated the constant imputation that the officials in Egypt were invanably wrong, otherwise bo sell respecting man would enter the service. The part government of Egypt bad crushed out from the race all the qualities essential to self goverument and the people had not yet soquired them. If the principles of self-government were applied too rapidly the result would be corruption, con fusion, disorder, and oppression. Sir Eldon Gorst has fully justified the anticipation that be would realise the hopes shared by Lond Cromer and the Government when he was appointed

He must be given time to form opinions impartially and without being pressed by instructions from England Reform must begin from below with powers over provincial conn cils and manicipalities, bat progress with representative institutions must be slow. In the meanwhile, the Imperial Government will use ita inftrance to ensure the government, though bureaucratic, being aiministeret justis and in a spirit of sympathy
The amendment was withdrawn (Rueter)
THE AUSTRALIAN SENATE.
A DEFENCE SCHEME

MELBOURNE, January 31 The Minister of Defence has laid before the Senate a defence scheme which provides for every made to undergo training between the ages of twelve and eighteen mi cadets and between eighteen and twenty six as national guards. All officers and non commissioned off oers are to pass through the ranks. It is esti mated that in eight years there will be 214,100 men trained and equipped for war. (Router)

There is a report here, which I am told is well founded that the Inniskilling Dragons are not destined to stay for any lengthener period among I am told that they will stay, swording to the present programme, until they are required to go to India for a tour of duty there. The regiment, comfortable it has been here, will not, I believe, regret to receive ita embarkation orders an India always offers attractions to the British soldier especially when be is a mounted man Indian service they tell me, will be in the nature of a novelty to the Inniskillings as scarcely any of them have done duty before in that command Certainly none of the officers have

div.head: KHEDIVIAL SPORTING CLUB
div.p: SECOND WINTER MEETING
THE KHEDIVE PRESENT.
A lovely still day had been evidently kept in reserve for us for our second day's racing Foggy in the morning the afternoon was perfect.

The Kbective honoured the moes with him presence, and when his Highness attende every thing seems to go well. The racing was good, the day fine, and the attendance by far the best we have had this year Prince Mohamed Ali Pasba Prince Youssouf Kamal Prince Omar Tomasoon and other notables were also present and took great interest in the racing The course was perfect going in the first moe Gouvernant in spite of bis weight romped in by a good 10 lengths He is a wonderful home for a second class country bread - and is an other instance of the good animals that can be bred in Egypt, it is a pity we have not more like him. Royal Medallist in the International Hanctionp wou his second race the meeting this was an excellent race to-day, Jenkins on Aurelios carrying a stone 10 ibe more weight was only a head behind. Lawrence rode a good Tace on the winner Carlton a length behind took third bonours
The Eclipse Stakes the big race of the year w third on the programme. The parimatoel did

besk trade, in fact the accomodation for selling the tickets provedl inantharent we are inform ad arrangements are now being made to give more space, and we hope that everyone will be able to buy their tickets more comfortably Patay after bis winning the Jubilee was made favourite at the pari mutuel, but Parlaan sold for most money at the lotterie. Boleh Bey Yzben stable bad many supporters An ex cellent field turned out no less than 16 starters Prom a good start Pares was first post the grand stand followed by Hakeem, Myntere and lahek. The race was very pretty one to watch. Padaan ran gamely and won good me well ridden by Stillwell, Patay second, Hakeem thind This lost mentioned home in a new one and apparently a good one. Ishak Bey Hussein has our best congratulations on his winning the big race and also on bir access in the last race wbere he was first and second.

For the Steeplechase, only three starters turned out Chater was most fancied but Petrone ran an excellent rare, Mr. Seymour, his pilot, giving him every chance and riding with skill and judgment Major Protheroe Smith, the very proud owner. Is having his turn of luck at last three races in two days in highly antintactory and be bas our hearty cott
ratulations Capt Leigh rode a good race on Cbster for second place Starboard Laght is Apparently not fit, but we expect to see him WIR A jump race soon

In the fifth race Badik male most of the running, but be weight told, and Stillwell bronght home Saiad Il first. He was sub sequently bought in by his owner at the anction The Galloway Handicap was triomph for Isbat Bey Hussein stable, taking first and econd placer

div.head: A DISGRACE TO ALEXANDRIA
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

Sir --Vindex's letter in your este of to day, criticising and finding fault with thine of 28th inst. is most interesting reading He first alludes to the Emperor Hadriani's opinion of the Alexandris of his day which, tongh no doubt a perfectly the one, quite les de the question, and owR to the civilisation, ought not p sibly to obtain He then accuses me of casting the responsibility for the absence a lite bont service from Alexandria on an innocent fellow country man, through my absolute ignorance of the facts of the case, and not taking the trouble to enquire I wrote a personal account of the wreck and the perilous position of the crew and commented strongly, but nothing like a I felt, or you, Sir, would rightly have refused to publish muy letter of the utter lack of anything being done to assist either these unfortunate seamen or their ill fated ship I said, that had a powerful tug come to her 188intance, even an hour and a half after the first signal of distress was hoisted, she might in my humble opinion, have been saved. Such
tog is I presume, to be found in the Harbour of Alexandria - If not why not and the sooner one is procure the better

"Vindex" informs that the liteboat question is only one of £d, and after repeated meetings and discussions between several authorities during the last five years, bad been allowed to die ont, owing to their ability to solve the problem how the necessary tands were to be provided What an miris sion!!! I thank "Vindex" for this information of which I was quite ignorant I now say it never ought to have been allowed to drop, and it is high time the subject was brought up again strongly, and not left until carried right through. There is more money wasted on unnecessary expenditure, and other things than would purchase anil endow several lite
hoata

I am perfectly aware that it creat Britain the lite boat services are entirely maintained by voluntary contributions I am proud of the fact But were it not so, I am certain that steps would have been taken long ere this, for a similar service, either by the State, or some public body. We cannot, perhaps, compare Egypt with Great Britain, but the argument that because the public will not come forward and provide the funds for such an institution, nothing should be done and no one is responsible, can hardly be sound Sne one is responsible, I way it emphatically. morally, if not legally and as we English have undertaken the task of shewing Egypt how to run herself on English lines na ATA possible, and therefore plared Englishmen in charge of most of the Departments it is at all unreasonable for me to cast the responsibility of this great want being still unsatisfied on the shoulders of a fellow country man
Yours truly,
AN INDIGNANT BRITISHER Windsor Hotel,

div.head: THE CAPITULATIONS
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

Sir, It is a matter of vital importance to this country to know whether Lord Cromer's scheme for the reform of the capitulations has been abandoned under the present régime or whether it is still proposed to carry it through. Some months ago unauthorised statement appeared in your columns contradicting the announcement made in a French local newspaper to the effect that the project had been abandoned Since then not a word has appeared on the subject We, the foreign colonies of Egypt are entitled to know what is being done in this most important matter, about which there should be no secret
Truly Yours
ANXIOUS ENQUIRER
JUST PUBLISHED
